div1.p: Lazear continues his sightseeing in Paris. He plans to sail on September 6.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 11, 1890
div1.p:
I received your letter
written at Bedford soon after I had written
my last letter to you. I am glad to
hear that you feel an improvement
and I hope it will continue. I
am sure that the water with the
change and surroundings generally
will do you much good. I received
by the same mail the “Bulletin” and
the “Bedford” paper.

I have been going on with my
sightseeing here. On Friday Saturday
I went to the Louvre, to the Jardin des
Plantes, and I to the place where the
Gobelin Tapestry is made. The Gobelin
Tapestry is beautiful, the coloring is
wonderful. The Jardin des Plantes is not
to be compared to the Kew Gardens nor is
the Menagerie to the one in London.
In the evening I went to the Theatre Francoise
and saw “Francois de Champi” and “Les
Petit Oiseaux”, Coquelin (cadet) playing
in the latter. They have a splendid
company. The theatre is very fine
but not as magnificent as the opera.
They are both supported by the Government.
Yesterday (Sunday) I went to the Louvre
and in the evening I went up to
the top of the Eiffel Tower. I went up
about seven o'clock just at Sunset.
It was clear and the view was
excellent. They keep the Galleries, Museums etc. open on Sunday here
in order to give the people a chance to
see them, and then they close them
on Monday to give the attendants
a rest. It seems to me to be a
very good plan.

The Boulevards here are magnificent,
great broad streets, broad sidewalks
with rows of trees. Then strings of
little tables in front of the cafes
with people sitting and drinking.
Here everybody drinks openly and yet
there is no drunkenness. Beer is
the usual drink and they drink it
slowly and they never take too much.
You occasionally see people drinking
Absinthe but it is not as common
as I had supposed. There is also
a great deal of coffee drunk in
front of the cafes. I always take
my coffee in that way after dinner.

I received your letter this morning
which you wrote at Cumberland. I am
sorry you did not make a longer stay
at Bedford. I supposed that you would
stay there three weeks at least. You
should have stayed until the worst of
the hot weather was over.

Yesterday I went with Norris and Knapp
to the Medical School and we spent
most of the afternoon in the Museum
which is very fine. We then went
to the Morgue and to the cathedral
of Notre-Dame which is near there.
In the evening we went to the
“Bouffes Parisiens” where they were
playing a pantomime called “L'Enfant
Prodigue” (Prodigal Son). It was very
good indeed although the theatre is
a very small affair. Today I have
been at the Musee de Luxembourg
looking at the modern paintings
and sculpture. There are a great
many excellent things there including
Marie Bashkirtseff's “Meeting”. I
afterwards went to the “Bon Marche”
which disappointed me. This
sightseeing is a very tiresome
business and I will be glad when
it is over. Norris and I will leave
Paris about Friday and go to the
Rhine probably first to Heidelburg
and then take a walk. We will
not make any very decided plan
but we will wander down the
River. I will write to Baring's from
time to time where to send my
letters. We will certainly sail
on Sept. 6. I have given up all
hope of getting a berth for the
13th. I will try to get off two letters
a week but it is not probable that
they will reach you regularly so
you must not be worried.
You must take good care of
yourself while you are in Pittsburgh.
I think you will get along
better now that you are at
Uncle Tom's.
